Instrument.name: COSPIN-High Flux Telescope (HFT) for ULY
Instrument.description: The High Flux Telescope (HFT) is an advanced instrument developed to measure the fluxes of protons, helium, and heavier particles in contexts where conventional telescopes are rendered ineffective due to elevated particle intensities. It exhibits exceptional azimuthal resolution, making it capable of discerning highly collimated particle distributions, particularly over solar poles and within the magnetosphere of Jupiter. This paper details the design and operational parameters of the HFT, which features a compact silicon surface-barrier detector integrated with a fan-shaped aluminum collimator, providing a distinctive viewing aperture and energy cut-off designed to minimize low-energy contamination. The functionality of five discriminator channels allows for precise calibration and measurement across a range of particle energies, enabling the differentiation of particle species and effective management of high counting rates. Preliminary results from in-flight tests have demonstrated the operational reliability and expected count responses, supporting the integrity of the HFT data retrieval process. Furthermore, analyses indicate that the HFT successfully mitigates pile-up issues inherent to high flux environments, ensuring accurate measurements in regions of intense radiative activity. These findings contribute to our understanding of particle distributions in planetary magnetospheres, employing data collected during the HFT's operational period, which bridges the intersection of astrophysical research and spacecraft technology applications.
